_source.contentraw:
Indiana Republican Gov. Eric Holcomb signed a bill Friday evening prohibiting most abortions.

The new law bans the procedure except in cases of rape, incest and to protect the life and physical health of the mother. The rape and incest exceptions only apply in the first 10 weeks post-fertilization. Victims would not be required to sign a notarized affidavit attesting to an attack, which had previously been proposed.

Abortions will also be allowed if a fetus is diagnosed with a lethal anomaly.

_source.contentraw:
A federal judge has ordered the Biden administration to hand over communication documents between the federal government and big tech companies.

U.S. District Court Judge Terry Doughty, of the Western District of Louisiana, granted the order of discovery sought by Republican Attorneys General Eric Schmitt of Missouri and Jeff Landry of Louisiana.

President Joe Biden, members of his administration, and select social media companies must turn over documents and answer questions within the next 30 days during a discovery phase of a lawsuit alleging collusion to suppress freedom of speech, a court ruled.

The attorneys general of #Louisiana and #Missouri filed a lawsuit in May alleging #Biden and eight high-ranking members of his administration and the government #colluded with and/or coerced social media companies #Meta, #Twitter, and #YouTube to suppress ‚Äúdisfavored speakers, viewpoints, and content on social medial platforms.‚Äù

_source.contentraw:
LOL

The transportation is part of Abbott‚Äôs Operation Lone Star ‚Äì a multi-agency effort to apprehend migrants who are illegally crossing the United States-Mexico border. The governor‚Äôs office reports over 290,700 illegal immigrants and 325.9 million doses of illicit fentanyl have been apprehended through the initiative.

Abbott has bused over 6,500 migrants to Washington D.C ‚Äúto provide much-needed relief to [Texas‚Äôs] overwhelmed border communities‚Äù since April when he began the relocation operation, which is being managed by the Texas Division of Emergency Management.

On Monday, Abbott sent a letter to DC Mayor Muriel Bowser and New York City Mayor Eric Adams inviting them to observe the ‚Äúhumanitarian and security crisis‚Äù on the nation‚Äôs southern border in person.

‚ÄúYour recent interest in this historic and preventable crisis is a welcome development‚Äîespecially as the President and his Administration have shown no remorse for their actions nor desire to address the situation themselves,‚Äù the governor wrote. ‚ÄúAs Governor, I invite you to visit our border region to see firsthand the dire situation that only grows more urgent with each passing day, and to meet with the local officials, who like yourselves, realize this matter deserves immediate federal action.‚Äù

‚ÄúI also ask you to join me in requesting President Biden secure the border and put an end to this disastrous crisis,‚Äù Abbott added.

Both Bowser and Adams requested in July for the Biden administration to send them assistance due to the burden a large number of illegal migrants has placed on their cities‚Äô resources, including homeless shelters.

Fabien Levy, a spokesperson for Adams, issued a written statement turning down the invitation.

‚ÄúInstead of a photo-op at the border, we hope Gov. Abbott will focus his energy and resources on providing support and resources to asylum seekers in Texas as we have been hard at work doing in New York City,‚Äù Levy wrote, per The Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúWe continue to work with federal partners to receive additional financial resources immediately, but will never turn our backs on those in need who are arriving here.‚Äù

Abbott alluded to the statement from the mayor‚Äôs office while announcing the charter buses‚Äô arrival.

‚ÄúIn addition to Washington, D.C., New York City is the ideal destination for these migrants, who can receive the abundance of city services and housing that Mayor Eric Adams has boasted about within the sanctuary city,‚Äù Abbott said in a statement. ‚ÄúI hope he follows through on his promise of welcoming all migrants with open arms so that our overrun and overwhelmed border towns can find relief.‚Äù

_source.contentraw:
Theme for a thriller genre fiction book.

1. Two really pissed-off American millionaires head off to Kosovo in Europe in search of some of the 70% of U.S. weapons destined for Ukraine which have gone missing.

2. Quite soon, they find an Albanian Mafia boss ready to sell them an artillery weapon, with munitions. The Mafia boss even offers to smuggle the weapon to the East Coast in a shipping container, for an additional fee.

3. 2 months later, the artillery weapon enclosed in a container labeled "BMW" arrives at New York Harbor. The chances of being inspected are very low since only a small sample of shipping containers are ever inspected, usually based on intelligence, i.e. government spies in criminal organizations. This ruthless Albanian Mafia outfit has very strict security and instant execution of snitches, therefore - no intel for the authorities.

4. The container is then loaded onto a truck and delivered to one of the Americans in a secluded forest about 20 miles away from Bethesda.

5. The other American is parked near 511 Edgemore Lane, Bethesda, MD 20814. But not too near to avoid detection. He is dressed like a plainclothes government agent, with a car to match. He uses binoculars to maintain surveillance.

6. Shortly after nightfall, he texts his friend in the forest: "BACK HOME". Both are using Eric Prince's encrypted secure comms platform.

7. BANG!!

card.title: World Economic Forum attacks idea of private property, natural rights

_source.content: World Economic Forum attacks idea of private property, natural rightsAmerican Thinker ^ | 31 Jul, 2022 | Eric Utterhttps://www.americanthinker.com/blog/2022/07/world_economic_forum_attacks_idea_of_private_property_natural_rights.htmlThe World Economic Forum is pushing for a global transition away from private ownership of vehicles and other "idle equipment" as part of a "clean energy revolution,‚Äù itself part of the Great Reset.‚Ä¶The first of these is the most important, and surely the most arousing to the likes of Klaus Schwab (son of a former member of several National Socialist (i.e. Nazi) organizations, and his ilk. The report argues that private ownership of vehicles and electronic devices, et. al., is wasteful and inefficient, and that we must ‚Äúgo from owning to using.‚ÄùIt further notes, "The average car or van in England is driven just 4% of the time,‚Äù and adds, ‚ÄúWhile most already have a personal phone, 39% of workers globally have employer-provided laptops and mobile phones. This is not at all resource efficient." Right. No one should be allowed to own more than one of anything.Memo to the WEF: one doesn‚Äôt live in one‚Äôs house, condo or apartment every hour of every day, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we shouldn‚Äôt own one‚Ä¶or that it is ‚Äúresource inefficient.‚Äù And how often do we use our toasters? Five minutes a day? That would be about three-tenths of one percent of the time. Our blenders? Washing machines, dryers? Televisions? Most folks don‚Äôt use their heat for several months out of the year. The same goes for air-conditioning. I guess we should get rid of all these ‚Äúidle, wasteful, and inefficient items,‚Äù too. Maybe we could call for a toaster, washing machine or T.V.-- if and when we need one.
_source.contentraw:
World Economic Forum attacks idea of private property, natural rights
American Thinker ^ | 31 Jul, 2022 | Eric Utter
https://www.americanthinker.com/blog/2022/07/world_economic_forum_attacks_idea_of_private_property_natural_rights.html

The World Economic Forum is pushing for a global transition away from private ownership of vehicles and other "idle equipment" as part of a "clean energy revolution,‚Äù itself part of the Great Reset.
‚Ä¶
The first of these is the most important, and surely the most arousing to the likes of Klaus Schwab (son of a former member of several National Socialist (i.e. Nazi) organizations, and his ilk. The report argues that private ownership of vehicles and electronic devices, et. al., is wasteful and inefficient, and that we must ‚Äúgo from owning to using.‚Äù

It further notes, "The average car or van in England is driven just 4% of the time,‚Äù and adds, ‚ÄúWhile most already have a personal phone, 39% of workers globally have employer-provided laptops and mobile phones. This is not at all resource efficient." Right. No one should be allowed to own more than one of anything.

Memo to the WEF: one doesn‚Äôt live in one‚Äôs house, condo or apartment every hour of every day, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we shouldn‚Äôt own one‚Ä¶or that it is ‚Äúresource inefficient.‚Äù And how often do we use our toasters? Five minutes a day? That would be about three-tenths of one percent of the time. Our blenders? Washing machines, dryers? Televisions? Most folks don‚Äôt use their heat for several months out of the year. The same goes for air-conditioning. I guess we should get rid of all these ‚Äúidle, wasteful, and inefficient items,‚Äù too. Maybe we could call for a toaster, washing machine or T.V.-- if and when we need one.
